Detective Maria Santos had always prided herself on being unflappable. Twenty-three years on the Pittsburgh police force had shown her every conceivable horror the human condition could produce, from domestic violence calls in the Hill District to complex homicide investigations that kept her awake for days. She'd faced down armed suspects, talked jumpers off bridges, and walked through crime scenes that made seasoned veterans reach for their antacids. But none of that prepared her for what happened on a muggy Tuesday morning in August when she responded to what should have been a routine noise complaint at an illegal cockfighting ring in Homewood.

The call came in at seven-fifteen AM, just as Maria was finishing her second cup of coffee and reviewing case files at her desk in Zone 5. Mrs. Eleanor Kowalski, eighty-three years old and sharp as a tack, had phoned to report "unholy screeching" coming from the abandoned warehouse behind her house. Maria expected to find teenagers with a boom box or maybe squatters, not the elaborate setup she discovered when she kicked down the warped wooden door.

The smell hit her first—sawdust, blood, and something else she couldn't identify but that made her stomach clench. Then came the sounds: men shouting, money changing hands, and underneath it all, an aggressive crowing that seemed to pierce straight through her eardrums and lodge itself in her brain. She radioed for backup and moved deeper into the warehouse, her service weapon drawn but pointed down.

What she saw would replay in her nightmares for months afterward. The makeshift arena occupied the center of the space, surrounded by bleachers cobbled together from old pallets and plywood. Fifty or sixty men crowded around the pit, their faces flushed with excitement and aggression, waving crumpled bills and screaming encouragement at the two birds locked in mortal combat below. The roosters themselves were magnificent and terrible—one glossy black with emerald tail feathers, the other rust-colored with a comb red as fresh blood. They moved with deadly grace, their razor-sharp spurs catching the harsh fluorescent lights as they lunged and retreated.

Maria had seen violence before, plenty of it, but something about this primal scene triggered a response she'd never experienced. Her hands began to shake, her breathing became shallow, and sweat broke out across her forehead despite the morning chill. The black rooster suddenly reared up on its legs and released a piercing crow of victory, and Maria felt her knees buckle.

She barely managed to maintain her composure long enough for backup to arrive and for the arrests to be processed. Forty-seven men were charged with illegal gambling and animal cruelty, the birds were confiscated by animal control, and the warehouse was sealed pending further investigation. But Maria couldn't shake the memory of that sound, the way it had seemed to reach inside her chest and squeeze her heart like a fist.

Her partner, Detective Ray Kowalski—no relation to the elderly complainant—noticed her distraction during the paperwork phase. Ray was built like a refrigerator with legs, all shoulders and gut, but he had the observational skills of a jeweler examining diamonds. He'd worked with Maria for eight years and had never seen her rattled by anything more serious than bad coffee from the precinct machine.

"You okay there, Santos?" he asked, glancing up from his incident report. "You look like you seen a ghost."

Maria forced a smile and shuffled her papers into order. "Fine. Just tired. Linda's been keeping me up with her wedding plans." It wasn't entirely a lie—her best friend Linda Chen had indeed been obsessing over every detail of her upcoming nuptials for the past six months—but it wasn't the real reason for her discomfort.

The next morning brought another rooster encounter, this one seemingly innocent. Maria was grabbing breakfast at Pamela's Diner in Shadyside, a ritual she'd maintained since her rookie days, when the cook's pet rooster wandered out of the kitchen area. The bird was small and harmless, probably some exotic breed that the eccentric owner kept as a mascot, but the moment Maria heard its tentative morning crow, her coffee cup slipped from nerveless fingers and shattered on the linoleum floor.The elderly waitress, Dolores, rushed over with a towel and dustpan, clucking her tongue in sympathy. She'd been serving Maria the same breakfast—two eggs over easy, wheat toast, and black coffee—for the better part of a decade, and she'd never seen the detective so jumpy. "Honey, you sure you're alright? You look pale as printer paper." Dolores had worked at Pamela's for thirty-seven years and prided herself on reading people, especially the cops who frequented the place. She'd seen them come and go, watched rookie officers transform into grizzled veterans, witnessed the toll the job took on even the strongest personalities. But Maria Santos had always been different, steady as granite and twice as unshakeable.

Maria mumbled an apology and threw a ten-dollar bill on the table, far more than her usual breakfast cost, before hurrying out into the morning air. The August heat was already building despite the early hour, and the humidity made her uniform shirt stick to her back in uncomfortable patches. She sat in her patrol car for several minutes, gripping the steering wheel and trying to understand what was happening to her. Twenty-three years of police work had exposed her to every form of human depravity, from child abuse cases that made her question the fundamental goodness of humanity to drug-related murders that painted Pittsburgh's streets with blood. She'd maintained her psychological equilibrium through it all, never once requiring the department-mandated counseling that claimed so many of her colleagues.

The radio crackled to life, dispatching her to a domestic disturbance call on Penn Avenue. Maria welcomed the distraction and drove toward the address, weaving through the morning traffic with practiced ease. Pittsburgh was waking up around her—delivery trucks making their rounds, commuters clutching coffee cups as they hurried toward bus stops, shopkeepers raising their metal security grates and preparing for another day of commerce. The familiar rhythm of the city usually comforted her, but today everything felt slightly off-kilter, as if she were viewing her world through a subtly distorted lens.

The domestic call turned out to be routine—a separated couple arguing over custody arrangements, their voices raised but no physical violence involved. Maria had mediated hundreds of similar disputes, and she fell back on her standard protocols: separate the parties, listen to both sides, de-escalate the emotions, and refer them to the appropriate social services. The familiar routine helped restore some of her confidence, and by the time she returned to her patrol car, she'd almost convinced herself that the morning's episode at the diner had been nothing more than fatigue and too much caffeine.

That illusion lasted exactly forty-three minutes, until she responded to a traffic accident near the Strip District and discovered that one of the vehicles involved was a truck transporting live chickens to a processing plant. The driver, a weathered man in his sixties named Frank Kowalski—the third person with that surname she'd encountered in two days, though this one actually was related to the elderly complainant who'd called in the cockfighting report—had taken a corner too fast and lost several dozen birds when his cargo doors sprang open. The chickens scattered across the street in a chaos of feathers and frantic clucking, creating both a traffic hazard and a minor spectacle as bystanders tried to help corral the escapees.

Maria stepped out of her patrol car to assess the situation, and immediately the world tilted sideways. The collective sound of dozens of chickens, their distressed cries mixing with the occasional crow from the few roosters in the group, hit her like a physical blow. Her vision blurred at the edges, her heart began racing, and she felt the familiar sensation of her hands starting to shake. She grabbed the car door for support, fighting against the wave of inexplicable terror that threatened to overwhelm her. This wasn't just fatigue or stress—something fundamental had shifted in her psychological makeup, and she had no idea what had triggered it or how to make it stop.Frank Kowalski climbed down from his truck cab, cursing under his breath in a mixture of English and what sounded like Polish. His weathered face was creased with worry as he surveyed the feathered chaos spreading across the intersection. "Twenty-seven years I been driving this route," he muttered to Maria, apparently assuming she was in a condition to help coordinate the cleanup effort. "Never had nothing like this happen before. That damn latch must've worked itself loose on the turn. Insurance is gonna have my hide, and the processing plant's gonna dock my pay for every bird we lose."

Maria nodded weakly, still gripping her car door and trying to regulate her breathing. The chickens continued their frantic scurrying, and she found herself cataloging each individual sound they made—the high-pitched distress calls of the hens, the deeper warning crows of the roosters, even the rustling of feathers against asphalt. Each noise seemed amplified in her consciousness, as if someone had turned up the volume on a frequency she'd never been able to hear before. She watched a large red rooster strut defiantly in front of a stopped city bus, its head held high and its chest puffed out in a display of territorial aggression that should have been comical but instead filled her with an inexplicable dread.

Several Good Samaritans had joined the effort to recapture the escaped birds, including a group of construction workers from a nearby site who seemed to find the whole situation highly entertaining. Their laughter and jokes provided a counterpoint to the animal sounds, but Maria barely heard their human voices. Instead, she found herself unconsciously tracking each rooster's movement, noting the hierarchy that seemed to be establishing itself even in the midst of chaos. The red rooster was clearly dominant, but a smaller black and gold bird was challenging its authority with increasingly bold displays of aggression.

Her radio crackled with a request for her status, and Maria forced herself to respond professionally despite the tremor in her voice. "Unit 247 on scene at traffic incident involving livestock," she managed to say. "Requesting Animal Control assistance and additional units for traffic direction." The dispatcher's acknowledgment seemed to come from very far away, and Maria realized that her peripheral vision was starting to narrow, a warning sign she recognized from academy training on stress responses and panic disorders.

The irony wasn't lost on her that she was having what appeared to be a panic attack in the middle of a street full of chickens while wearing a police uniform that represented authority and competence. She'd talked other people through similar episodes, using the standard techniques of controlled breathing and cognitive reframing that the department psychologists recommended. But knowing the theory and applying it to yourself while surrounded by the specific trigger of your distress proved to be entirely different challenges.

Frank Kowalski continued his running commentary on the situation, apparently unaware of Maria's deteriorating condition. "That red one there, he's gonna be trouble," he said, pointing at the dominant rooster. "Been trying to start fights with the other males since we loaded him this morning. Some birds just got that aggressive streak, you know? Breeding, probably. These commercial operations, they don't always pay attention to temperament when they're selecting their stock." His words seemed to echo strangely in Maria's ears, and she found herself wondering if there was some deeper meaning hidden in his casual observations about animal behavior and inherited aggression.

A young woman in scrubs, probably heading to or from a shift at one of the nearby hospitals, stopped to help corral a group of white hens that had taken refuge under a parked car. "Are you okay, officer?" she asked Maria, her voice carrying the professional concern of someone trained to recognize medical distress. "You're looking pretty pale, and you're breathing kind of fast. Maybe you should sit down for a minute."

Maria wanted to accept the suggestion, but her training and her pride wouldn't allow her to show weakness in front of civilians, especially when she was supposed to be the one managing the situation. Instead, she straightened her shoulders and attempted to project an air of professional competence, even though her internal world was spinning out of control. "Just hot out here," she said, wiping sweat from her forehead with the back of her hand. "August in Pittsburgh, you know how it is."

The woman in scrubs didn't look convinced, but she returned her attention to the chickens without pushing the issue. Maria silently blessed her for that small mercy, because she wasn't sure she could have maintained the facade much longer under direct questioning. She pulled out her notepad and began documenting the incident, focusing on the familiar routine of police paperwork as an anchor to normal reality. The act of writing helped steady her hands and gave her something to concentrate on other than the increasingly complex social dynamics playing out among the escaped birds.

Animal Control arrived within fifteen minutes, bringing specialized equipment and the expertise needed to safely capture the scattered chickens. Maria watched with professional interest as they deployed nets and carriers, working with an efficiency that spoke of considerable experience with similar situations. The lead Animal Control officer, a middle-aged African American woman whose name tag read "Johnson," approached Maria for a briefing on the situation.

"Looks like you got yourself a regular barnyard convention here," Johnson said with a grin that suggested she genuinely enjoyed her work. "How many birds we talking about, and do we know if any of them are injured?" Her casual attitude toward what Maria was experiencing as a crisis helped provide some perspective, and Maria felt her breathing begin to slow slightly as she focused on providing the requested information."Driver estimates about sixty birds total," Maria replied, consulting her notepad and grateful for the excuse to look away from the ongoing poultry drama. "Most of them scattered when the cargo doors opened, but I haven't seen any obvious injuries. The truck wasn't going very fast when it took the corner." She paused, watching Johnson survey the scene with the practiced eye of someone who had dealt with similar incidents many times before. The Animal Control officer's calm professionalism was oddly reassuring, suggesting that escaped livestock in urban Pittsburgh was more common than Maria had previously realized.

Johnson nodded and began directing her team with hand signals and brief verbal instructions. They moved with coordinated precision, forming a loose perimeter around the largest concentration of birds while leaving escape routes that would funnel the chickens toward their transport carriers. "The trick is not to panic them more than they already are," Johnson explained to Maria as they watched the operation unfold. "Birds this size, they can hurt themselves pretty bad if they get too worked up. Broken wings, heart attacks from stress, that kind of thing. Plus, a scared rooster can do some real damage if he decides you're a threat to his flock."

The mention of aggressive roosters made Maria's pulse quicken again, and she found herself unconsciously stepping back from the nearest group of birds. The red rooster that Frank had identified as a troublemaker was living up to his reputation, puffing his feathers and making threatening gestures toward anyone who came too close to the hens he'd apparently claimed as his territory. His crow seemed louder than the others, more commanding, and Maria felt her newly developed phobia respond with a fresh wave of irrational terror that she struggled to suppress.

Officer Johnson noticed Maria's reaction and gave her a curious look. "You okay there? You look like someone just walked over your grave." The expression was one Maria's grandmother had used frequently, and hearing it now in this context made her think about inherited fears and unexplained anxieties. Was it possible that some people were simply predisposed to develop specific phobias, the way others inherited tendencies toward heart disease or diabetes? The thought was simultaneously comforting and disturbing—comforting because it suggested her condition might have a biological explanation rather than representing some fundamental failure of character, but disturbing because it implied the problem might be permanent rather than something she could simply overcome through willpower and professional training.

"Just not used to dealing with livestock," Maria said, which was true enough even if it didn't fully explain the severity of her reaction. "Most of my calls involve human suspects who at least theoretically respond to verbal commands and legal authority. These birds seem to have their own agenda." She attempted a laugh, but it came out sounding forced and hollow even to her own ears. Johnson's expression suggested she wasn't entirely buying the casual explanation, but she was professional enough not to press the issue while they were still managing an active incident.

The Animal Control team had succeeded in corralling about half of the escaped chickens, working with a combination of patience and strategic positioning that reminded Maria of certain types of police operations. The birds were loaded into transport carriers that would take them to a temporary holding facility while the insurance companies and legal departments sorted out liability issues. Frank Kowalski stood near his damaged truck, filling out paperwork and shaking his head periodically as he calculated the financial impact of the morning's disaster.

"Twenty-seven years," he repeated to anyone within earshot, as if the length of his employment record should have provided some protection against mechanical failures and escaped poultry. "Never had nothing like this happen before. That latch should've held. Gonna have to have a serious conversation with the maintenance department when I get back to the depot." His voice carried the resignation of a working man who understood that accidents happened regardless of experience or good intentions, but who still felt personally responsible for the chaos that had resulted from circumstances largely beyond his control.

Maria found herself oddly comforted by Frank's steady stream of commentary, partly because it gave her something to focus on other than the remaining birds, but also because his matter-of-fact acceptance of the situation helped normalize what she was experiencing. Accidents happened, even to people with decades of experience. Systems failed despite careful maintenance and proper procedures. Sometimes the world simply refused to cooperate with human plans and expectations, and the best anyone could do was adapt to changing circumstances and try to minimize the damage.

The philosophical implications of that realization struck her as potentially relevant to her own situation. Perhaps her sudden development of what appeared to be an intense phobia of roosters was simply another example of life's unpredictability, no different in principle from Frank's mechanical failure or the dozens of other random events that had shaped her police career. The thought didn't make her physical symptoms any less distressing, but it provided a framework for understanding her condition that didn't require self-blame or professional shame.

One of the Animal Control officers, a young man who looked barely old enough to have graduated from high school, was having trouble with a particularly stubborn group of hens that had taken refuge in the narrow space between two parked cars. His repeated attempts to guide them toward the transport carriers were being frustrated by their apparent determination to remain in what they perceived as a safe hiding spot. Johnson called out suggestions and encouragement, but the birds seemed to have developed their own strategy for dealing with the situation that didn't align with official capture protocols.

"Sometimes they just decide they like where they are," Johnson explained to Maria as they watched the young officer's increasingly creative attempts to dislodge the hiding birds. "Can't really blame them, when you think about it. From their perspective, they were minding their own business in a nice secure truck, and suddenly their whole world got turned upside down. Now they're in a strange place with unfamiliar sounds and smells, and everyone wants them to go somewhere else they've never seen before. Makes perfect sense they'd want to stay put once they found a spot that felt safe."

The parallel to Maria's own psychological state was so obvious that she wondered if Johnson was deliberately drawing the comparison or simply making casual conversation about animal behavior. Either way, the observation resonated with something deep in Maria's consciousness, a recognition that her sudden fear of roosters might represent her mind's attempt to create safety and predictability in a world that had somehow become more threatening than she'd previously realized. The idea that fear could be a rational response to perceived danger, even when that perception wasn't entirely accurate, suggested that her condition might be treatable rather than representing some fundamental character flaw.**Chapter 2**

The rest of Maria's shift passed without incident, but she found herself hyperaware of every sound that might remotely resemble a rooster's crow. Car horns seemed more piercing than usual, the screech of bus brakes made her flinch, and even the laughter of children playing in a schoolyard caused her to turn her head anxiously, searching for the source of what her nervous system interpreted as potential threats. By the time she returned to the precinct at the end of her tour, she felt mentally and physically exhausted in a way that had nothing to do with the actual demands of police work and everything to do with maintaining constant vigilance against an enemy that existed primarily in her own mind.

Ray Kowalski was waiting for her in the parking lot, leaning against his personal vehicle with the patient air of someone who had been there for a while. His presence wasn't entirely surprising—they often coordinated their schedules to grab dinner or drinks after particularly difficult shifts—but something in his expression suggested this wasn't a casual social invitation. He'd worked with enough cops over the years to recognize the signs of someone struggling with job-related stress, and Maria's recent behavior had triggered his professional concern as well as his personal friendship. The fact that she'd been partnered with him for eight years without ever showing signs of psychological distress only made her current condition more alarming from his perspective.

"We need to talk," he said without preamble, falling into step beside her as she walked toward her own car. "And before you tell me everything's fine, I already heard about the chicken truck incident this morning. Johnson from Animal Control called the precinct to ask if you were feeling okay, said you looked like you were about to pass out in the middle of Penn Avenue." His voice carried the gentle but firm tone he typically used when dealing with victims who were reluctant to discuss traumatic experiences, a technique he'd developed over two decades of police work and refined through countless interactions with people who preferred to minimize their own suffering rather than admit they needed help.

Maria's first instinct was to deflect with humor or redirect the conversation toward Ray's concerns, but the events of the past few days had left her feeling too drained for elaborate deceptions. She unlocked her car and sat in the driver's seat with the door open, staring at the steering wheel while she tried to formulate an explanation that wouldn't sound completely insane to her pragmatic partner. The problem was that she didn't really understand what was happening to herself, which made it difficult to provide reassuring explanations to anyone else. How could she tell Ray that she'd developed an irrational terror of barnyard birds without sounding like she was having some kind of mental breakdown?

"I think I might be developing a phobia," she said finally, the words feeling strange and unfamiliar in her mouth. "I know how that sounds, especially coming from someone who's been doing this job as long as I have, but something's changed in the last few days. Ever since that cockfighting bust, I can't seem to handle being around roosters without having what feels like a panic attack." The admission felt both liberating and terrifying, acknowledging the reality of her condition while simultaneously making it more concrete and therefore more threatening to her sense of professional identity.

Ray's expression shifted from concern to something that might have been relief, as if her willingness to discuss the problem represented progress toward solving it. He'd seen too many cops try to handle psychological difficulties on their own, usually with results that damaged both their personal lives and their professional effectiveness. The fact that Maria was recognizing and naming her condition suggested she retained enough self-awareness to potentially address it before it became career-threatening. "Phobias are treatable," he said, settling into a comfortable position against her car where they could talk privately without attracting attention from other officers. "My cousin developed one after a car accident, couldn't drive over bridges for almost two years. Went to a therapist who specialized in that kind of thing, and now she's fine. Takes time and work, but it's not permanent unless you ignore it."

The comparison to post-accident trauma was both encouraging and troubling for Maria, encouraging because it suggested her condition had precedent and established treatment protocols, but troubling because it implied some kind of psychological injury that she couldn't identify or remember experiencing. The cockfighting bust had been unpleasant but not particularly traumatic by police standards, certainly nothing compared to some of the violent crime scenes she'd processed over the years. What made that particular incident different enough to trigger such a dramatic psychological response? Was it possible that cumulative stress from decades of police work had finally reached some kind of tipping point, with roosters serving as an arbitrary focal point for anxieties that actually had much deeper roots?

"The thing is, I can't figure out what caused it," Maria said, voicing her confusion about the timing and specificity of her symptoms. "I've dealt with plenty of situations that were more objectively stressful than a bunch of guys betting on chicken fights. Remember that domestic violence call last month where the suspect had a shotgun and three hostages? Or the gang shooting in East Liberty where we had to secure a scene with four bodies while the neighbors were throwing bottles at us? Those situations were genuinely dangerous, but they didn't affect me like this. So why roosters? Why now? It doesn't make psychological sense."

Ray considered the question seriously, drawing on his own experiences with job-related stress and his observations of colleagues who'd struggled with various forms of burnout and trauma reactions. "Sometimes it's not about the specific incident," he said thoughtfully. "Sometimes it's about timing, or it's the thing that happens when you're already stretched thin from other stuff. Could be something completely unrelated to work that's making you more vulnerable to developing anxiety responses. How are things going with your mom's health situation? And didn't you mention Linda's wedding was stressing you out? Sometimes our brains pick weird ways to express stress that's really about something else entirely."

The mention of her mother's declining health hit closer to home than Maria was comfortable acknowledging, even to herself. Margaret Santos had been diagnosed with early-stage Alzheimer's disease six months earlier, and watching her vibrant, independent mother gradually lose pieces of herself had been more emotionally devastating than any crime scene Maria had ever worked. The progression was still relatively slow, but the knowledge that it would only get worse had created a constant background anxiety that colored every interaction between them. Maria had been handling the situation by focusing on practical concerns—researching care options, consulting with doctors, managing her mother's finances—while avoiding the deeper emotional implications of watching a parent disappear by degrees.

"Maybe you're right about the timing," Maria admitted reluctantly. "There's been a lot of stuff going on outside of work that I haven't really been dealing with. Mom's situation, Linda's wedding drama, even some financial pressure from helping cover Mom's medical expenses. I guess I've been using work as a way to avoid thinking about personal problems, and maybe that strategy finally stopped working." The realization felt both obvious and profound, like recognizing a pattern that had been visible all along but somehow outside her conscious awareness. How many times had she counseled crime victims about the delayed onset of trauma symptoms, explaining that psychological reactions didn't always follow logical timelines or focus on the most objectively serious incidents?

Ray nodded with the understanding of someone who'd seen similar patterns play out in his own life and career. "The job can be a great distraction from personal problems until it isn't," he said. "And when that coping mechanism breaks down, sometimes the symptoms show up in ways that don't seem directly connected to the real underlying issues. Your brain picked roosters as the thing to be afraid of, but maybe what you're really afraid of is losing control, or not being able to protect the people you care about, or having to face difficult emotional situations without your usual professional detachment." His analysis was uncomfortably perceptive, cutting through Maria's defensive rationalizations to identify fears she hadn't been willing to acknowledge even in her own internal dialogue.

The conversation was interrupted by the arrival of Sergeant Patricia Valdez, their immediate supervisor, who approached with the purposeful stride of someone delivering official information rather than engaging in casual conversation. Valdez had been promoted to sergeant three years earlier after distinguishing herself during a complex investigation involving police corruption, and she'd earned the respect of her subordinates through a combination of professional competence and genuine concern for officer welfare. Her presence in the parking lot after shift hours suggested she'd sought them out deliberately rather than encountering them by chance.

"Santos, glad I caught you before you left," Valdez said, though her expression suggested the conversation might not be entirely welcome from Maria's perspective. "I got a call from Captain Morrison about the incident with the chicken truck this morning. Nothing official, just him checking to make sure everything was handled properly and that you weren't experiencing any health issues that might affect your duty status." The carefully neutral language couldn't entirely disguise the implication that Maria's behavior had been noticed and evaluated by higher-ranking officials, which meant her condition was potentially becoming a matter of departmental record rather than remaining a private struggle she could manage independently.

Maria felt her chest tighten with anxiety that had nothing to do with roosters and everything to do with the potential threat to her career and professional reputation. Twenty-three years of exemplary service could be overshadowed by questions about her psychological fitness for duty, especially in a department that was increasingly sensitive to officer mental health issues following several high-profile incidents involving cops who'd exhibited erratic behavior before committing serious misconduct. The irony that her phobia involved harmless farm animals rather than legitimate threats to public safety wouldn't matter if her supervisors decided she was experiencing some form of psychological breakdown that compromised her effectiveness as a police officer.

"I'm fine, Sergeant," Maria said, trying to project confidence while simultaneously fighting the urge to provide elaborate explanations that might make her sound defensive or unstable. "It was a routine traffic incident that required Animal Control assistance. Officer Johnson and her team handled the livestock situation professionally, and I documented everything according to standard procedures. If Captain Morrison has questions about my report, I'm happy to discuss the details with him." The response was technically accurate while avoiding any mention of her personal psychological reactions to the incident, a careful balance between honesty and self-preservation that felt uncomfortably similar to the evasion tactics used by suspects during interrogations.

Valdez studied Maria's face with the analytical expression of someone trained to detect deception and evaluate credibility under pressure. "Morrison's not questioning your police work," she said after a moment. "But he is concerned about officer welfare, especially given the stress levels everyone's been under with the budget cuts and staffing shortages. If you're dealing with any personal issues that might benefit from counseling or other support services, the department has resources available. No stigma, no impact on your personnel file, just help if you need it." The offer was genuine and well-intentioned, but Maria couldn't shake the feeling that accepting assistance might be interpreted as an admission of weakness or unfitness for duty, regardless of official departmental policies about mental health support.

Ray cleared his throat diplomatically, drawing Valdez's attention away from Maria and providing a momentary break in the intensity of the conversation. "Sergeant, we were just discussing some stress management techniques that might help with the general job pressures everyone's been feeling lately," he said, smoothly reframing their conversation in terms that supported Maria while acknowledging the validity of supervisory concerns. "You know how it is—sometimes these high-stress situations accumulate over time, and it helps to have strategies for processing everything in a healthy way. Maria's been dealing with some family health issues on top of the regular job demands, which is something we can all relate to." His intervention was subtle but effective, normalizing Maria's situation while providing context that explained any unusual behavior without suggesting psychological instability.

The mention of family health issues seemed to resonate with Valdez, whose own mother had battled cancer the previous year while she was adjusting to her new supervisory responsibilities. The dual stress of personal crisis and professional obligations was something she understood from direct experience, and her expression softened with genuine sympathy rather than official concern. "Family health problems are tough," she said, her tone shifting from supervisory to personal. "It's hard to focus on work when you're worried about someone you love, and it's hard to be present for family when work keeps demanding your attention. If you need any schedule adjustments or temporary assignment modifications while you're dealing with your mom's situation, just let me know. We can work something out informally without making it a big administrative process."

The unexpected offer of flexibility and support caught Maria off guard, reminding her that her colleagues and supervisors were human beings with their own struggles rather than simply institutional representatives focused on liability and compliance issues. The realization that she didn't have to handle her problems entirely alone was both comforting and overwhelming, opening emotional floodgates she'd been working hard to keep closed. For a moment, she felt tears threatening to spill over, a reaction that would have been mortifying under normal circumstances but somehow felt appropriate given the genuine care being expressed by people she respected professionally and personally.

"Thank you, Sergeant," Maria managed to say, her voice slightly hoarse with suppressed emotion. "I appreciate the offer, and I'll definitely keep it in mind if things get more complicated with Mom's care situation. Right now I think I'm managing okay, but it helps to know there are options if that changes." The acknowledgment felt like a small step toward accepting help rather than maintaining the facade of complete self-sufficiency that had served her well throughout most of her career but was becoming increasingly difficult to sustain in the face of multiple stressors and unexpected psychological symptoms.

Valdez nodded and prepared to leave, but then paused as if remembering something important. "One more thing, Santos. I know this might seem unrelated, but there's been some talk about organizing a stress management workshop for the whole department, maybe bringing in someone from outside to talk about recognizing and dealing with cumulative job stress. Would you be interested in helping coordinate something like that? Your experience and credibility with the other officers would be valuable in getting people to actually participate instead of just viewing it as mandatory bureaucratic nonsense." The suggestion was clearly intended as both a genuine request for assistance and an opportunity for Maria to address her own issues while helping colleagues, a approach that appealed to her service-oriented personality while providing cover for seeking professional guidance.

The idea of organizing a department-wide stress management program was actually appealing to Maria, partly because it would allow her to research coping strategies and treatment options under the guise of helping others, but also because it aligned with her natural inclination to solve problems through action rather than simply accepting them as unchangeable circumstances. If she was going to deal with her rooster phobia and the underlying anxiety it represented, she might as well do it in a way that could benefit other officers who were struggling with their own job-related psychological challenges. The approach would also provide a socially acceptable framework for accessing professional mental health resources without appearing to admit personal weakness or unfitness for duty.

"That sounds like a worthwhile project," Maria replied, feeling genuinely interested in the proposal for the first time in their conversation. "I'd be happy to help coordinate something like that. Do you have any specific ideas about format or content, or would you want me to research options and come back with recommendations?" The shift from discussing her personal problems to planning a constructive program that could help multiple people felt energizing rather than draining, suggesting that her fundamental problem-solving instincts remained intact despite her recent psychological difficulties.

Valdez smiled with what appeared to be genuine pleasure at Maria's positive response. "Why don't you start by researching what other departments have done and what kinds of resources are available locally," she suggested. "Talk to a few people, get some cost estimates, maybe reach out to the police union to make sure they're on board with the concept. We can schedule a meeting in a couple of weeks to discuss your findings and start putting together a concrete proposal for the captain. This could be really beneficial for everyone, especially given how stretched thin we've all been lately." The enthusiasm in her voice suggested that the stress management program idea had been something she'd been considering for a while rather than a spontaneous response to concerns about Maria's condition.

Detective Maria Santos had always prided herself on being unflappable. Twenty-three years on the Pittsburgh police force had shown her every conceivable horror the human condition could produce, from domestic violence calls in the Hill District to complex homicide investigations that kept her awake for days. She'd faced down armed suspects, talked jumpers off bridges, and walked through crime scenes that made seasoned veterans reach for their antacids. But none of that prepared her for what happened on a muggy Tuesday morning in August when she responded to what should have been a routine noise complaint at an illegal cockfighting ring in Homewood.

The call came in at seven-fifteen AM, just as Maria was finishing her second cup of coffee and reviewing case files at her desk in Zone 5. Mrs. Eleanor Kowalski, eighty-three years old and sharp as a tack, had phoned to report "unholy screeching" coming from the abandoned warehouse behind her house. Maria expected to find teenagers with a boom box or maybe squatters, not the elaborate setup she discovered when she kicked down the warped wooden door.

The smell hit her first—sawdust, blood, and something else she couldn't identify but that made her stomach clench. Then came the sounds: men shouting, money changing hands, and underneath it all, an aggressive crowing that seemed to pierce straight through her eardrums and lodge itself in her brain. She radioed for backup and moved deeper into the warehouse, her service weapon drawn but pointed down.

What she saw would replay in her nightmares for months afterward. The makeshift arena occupied the center of the space, surrounded by bleachers cobbled together from old pallets and plywood. Fifty or sixty men crowded around the pit, their faces flushed with excitement and aggression, waving crumpled bills and screaming encouragement at the two birds locked in mortal combat below. The roosters themselves were magnificent and terrible—one glossy black with emerald tail feathers, the other rust-colored with a comb red as fresh blood. They moved with deadly grace, their razor-sharp spurs catching the harsh fluorescent lights as they lunged and retreated.

Maria had seen violence before, plenty of it, but something about this primal scene triggered a response she'd never experienced. Her hands began to shake, her breathing became shallow, and sweat broke out across her forehead despite the morning chill. The black rooster suddenly reared up on its legs and released a piercing crow of victory, and Maria felt her knees buckle.

She barely managed to maintain her composure long enough for backup to arrive and for the arrests to be processed. Forty-seven men were charged with illegal gambling and animal cruelty, the birds were confiscated by animal control, and the warehouse was sealed pending further investigation. But Maria couldn't shake the memory of that sound, the way it had seemed to reach inside her chest and squeeze her heart like a fist.

Her partner, Detective Ray Kowalski—no relation to the elderly complainant—noticed her distraction during the paperwork phase. Ray was built like a refrigerator with legs, all shoulders and gut, but he had the observational skills of a jeweler examining diamonds. He'd worked with Maria for eight years and had never seen her rattled by anything more serious than bad coffee from the precinct machine.

"You okay there, Santos?" he asked, glancing up from his incident report. "You look like you seen a ghost."

Maria forced a smile and shuffled her papers into order. "Fine. Just tired. Linda's been keeping me up with her wedding plans." It wasn't entirely a lie—her best friend Linda Chen had indeed been obsessing over every detail of her upcoming nuptials for the past six months—but it wasn't the real reason for her discomfort.

The next morning brought another rooster encounter, this one seemingly innocent. Maria was grabbing breakfast at Pamela's Diner in Shadyside, a ritual she'd maintained since her rookie days, when the cook's pet rooster wandered out of the kitchen area. The bird was small and harmless, probably some exotic breed that the eccentric owner kept as a mascot, but the moment Maria heard its tentative morning crow, her coffee cup slipped from nerveless fingers and shattered on the linoleum floor.

The elderly waitress, Dolores, rushed over with a towel and dustpan, clucking her tongue in sympathy. She'd been serving Maria the same breakfast—two eggs over easy, wheat toast, and black coffee—for the better part of a decade, and she'd never seen the detective so jumpy. "Honey, you sure you're alright? You look pale as printer paper." Dolores had worked at Pamela's for thirty-seven years and prided herself on reading people, especially the cops who frequented the place. She'd seen them come and go, watched rookie officers transform into grizzled veterans, witnessed the toll the job took on even the strongest personalities. But Maria Santos had always been different, steady as granite and twice as unshakeable.

Maria mumbled an apology and threw a ten-dollar bill on the table, far more than her usual breakfast cost, before hurrying out into the morning air. The August heat was already building despite the early hour, and the humidity made her uniform shirt stick to her back in uncomfortable patches. She sat in her patrol car for several minutes, gripping the steering wheel and trying to understand what was happening to her. Twenty-three years of police work had exposed her to every form of human depravity, from child abuse cases that made her question the fundamental goodness of humanity to drug-related murders that painted Pittsburgh's streets with blood. She'd maintained her psychological equilibrium through it all, never once requiring the department-mandated counseling that claimed so many of her colleagues.

The radio crackled to life, dispatching her to a domestic disturbance call on Penn Avenue. Maria welcomed the distraction and drove toward the address, weaving through the morning traffic with practiced ease. Pittsburgh was waking up around her—delivery trucks making their rounds, commuters clutching coffee cups as they hurried toward bus stops, shopkeepers raising their metal security grates and preparing for another day of commerce. The familiar rhythm of the city usually comforted her, but today everything felt slightly off-kilter, as if she were viewing her world through a subtly distorted lens.

The domestic call turned out to be routine—a separated couple arguing over custody arrangements, their voices raised but no physical violence involved. Maria had mediated hundreds of similar disputes, and she fell back on her standard protocols: separate the parties, listen to both sides, de-escalate the emotions, and refer them to the appropriate social services. The familiar routine helped restore some of her confidence, and by the time she returned to her patrol car, she'd almost convinced herself that the morning's episode at the diner had been nothing more than fatigue and too much caffeine.

That illusion lasted exactly forty-three minutes, until she responded to a traffic accident near the Strip District and discovered that one of the vehicles involved was a truck transporting live chickens to a processing plant. The driver, a weathered man in his sixties named Frank Kowalski—the third person with that surname she'd encountered in two days, though this one actually was related to the elderly complainant who'd called in the cockfighting report—had taken a corner too fast and lost several dozen birds when his cargo doors sprang open. The chickens scattered across the street in a chaos of feathers and frantic clucking, creating both a traffic hazard and a minor spectacle as bystanders tried to help corral the escapees.

Maria stepped out of her patrol car to assess the situation, and immediately the world tilted sideways. The collective sound of dozens of chickens, their distressed cries mixing with the occasional crow from the few roosters in the group, hit her like a physical blow. Her vision blurred at the edges, her heart began racing, and she felt the familiar sensation of her hands starting to shake. She grabbed the car door for support, fighting against the wave of inexplicable terror that threatened to overwhelm her. This wasn't just fatigue or stress—something fundamental had shifted in her psychological makeup, and she had no idea what had triggered it or how to make it stop.

Frank Kowalski climbed down from his truck cab, cursing under his breath in a mixture of English and what sounded like Polish. His weathered face was creased with worry as he surveyed the feathered chaos spreading across the intersection. "Twenty-seven years I been driving this route," he muttered to Maria, apparently assuming she was in a condition to help coordinate the cleanup effort. "Never had nothing like this happen before. That damn latch must've worked itself loose on the turn. Insurance is gonna have my hide, and the processing plant's gonna dock my pay for every bird we lose."

Maria nodded weakly, still gripping her car door and trying to regulate her breathing. The chickens continued their frantic scurrying, and she found herself cataloging each individual sound they made—the high-pitched distress calls of the hens, the deeper warning crows of the roosters, even the rustling of feathers against asphalt. Each noise seemed amplified in her consciousness, as if someone had turned up the volume on a frequency she'd never been able to hear before. She watched a large red rooster strut defiantly in front of a stopped city bus, its head held high and its chest puffed out in a display of territorial aggression that should have been comical but instead filled her with an inexplicable dread.

Several Good Samaritans had joined the effort to recapture the escaped birds, including a group of construction workers from a nearby site who seemed to find the whole situation highly entertaining. Their laughter and jokes provided a counterpoint to the animal sounds, but Maria barely heard their human voices. Instead, she found herself unconsciously tracking each rooster's movement, noting the hierarchy that seemed to be establishing itself even in the midst of chaos. The red rooster was clearly dominant, but a smaller black and gold bird was challenging its authority with increasingly bold displays of aggression.

Her radio crackled with a request for her status, and Maria forced herself to respond professionally despite the tremor in her voice. "Unit 247 on scene at traffic incident involving livestock," she managed to say. "Requesting Animal Control assistance and additional units for traffic direction." The dispatcher's acknowledgment seemed to come from very far away, and Maria realized that her peripheral vision was starting to narrow, a warning sign she recognized from academy training on stress responses and panic disorders.

The irony wasn't lost on her that she was having what appeared to be a panic attack in the middle of a street full of chickens while wearing a police uniform that represented authority and competence. She'd talked other people through similar episodes, using the standard techniques of controlled breathing and cognitive reframing that the department psychologists recommended. But knowing the theory and applying it to yourself while surrounded by the specific trigger of your distress proved to be entirely different challenges.

Frank Kowalski continued his running commentary on the situation, apparently unaware of Maria's deteriorating condition. "That red one there, he's gonna be trouble," he said, pointing at the dominant rooster. "Been trying to start fights with the other males since we loaded him this morning. Some birds just got that aggressive streak, you know? Breeding, probably. These commercial operations, they don't always pay attention to temperament when they're selecting their stock." His words seemed to echo strangely in Maria's ears, and she found herself wondering if there was some deeper meaning hidden in his casual observations about animal behavior and inherited aggression.

A young woman in scrubs, probably heading to or from a shift at one of the nearby hospitals, stopped to help corral a group of white hens that had taken refuge under a parked car. "Are you okay, officer?" she asked Maria, her voice carrying the professional concern of someone trained to recognize medical distress. "You're looking pretty pale, and you're breathing kind of fast. Maybe you should sit down for a minute."

Maria wanted to accept the suggestion, but her training and her pride wouldn't allow her to show weakness in front of civilians, especially when she was supposed to be the one managing the situation. Instead, she straightened her shoulders and attempted to project an air of professional competence, even though her internal world was spinning out of control. "Just hot out here," she said, wiping sweat from her forehead with the back of her hand. "August in Pittsburgh, you know how it is."

The woman in scrubs didn't look convinced, but she returned her attention to the chickens without pushing the issue. Maria silently blessed her for that small mercy, because she wasn't sure she could have maintained the facade much longer under direct questioning. She pulled out her notepad and began documenting the incident, focusing on the familiar routine of police paperwork as an anchor to normal reality. The act of writing helped steady her hands and gave her something to concentrate on other than the increasingly complex social dynamics playing out among the escaped birds.

Animal Control arrived within fifteen minutes, bringing specialized equipment and the expertise needed to safely capture the scattered chickens. Maria watched with professional interest as they deployed nets and carriers, working with an efficiency that spoke of considerable experience with similar situations. The lead Animal Control officer, a middle-aged African American woman whose name tag read "Johnson," approached Maria for a briefing on the situation.

"Looks like you got yourself a regular barnyard convention here," Johnson said with a grin that suggested she genuinely enjoyed her work. "How many birds we talking about, and do we know if any of them are injured?" Her casual attitude toward what Maria was experiencing as a crisis helped provide some perspective, and Maria felt her breathing begin to slow slightly as she focused on providing the requested information.

"Driver estimates about sixty birds total," Maria replied, consulting her notepad and grateful for the excuse to look away from the ongoing poultry drama. "Most of them scattered when the cargo doors opened, but I haven't seen any obvious injuries. The truck wasn't going very fast when it took the corner." She paused, watching Johnson survey the scene with the practiced eye of someone who had dealt with similar incidents many times before. The Animal Control officer's calm professionalism was oddly reassuring, suggesting that escaped livestock in urban Pittsburgh was more common than Maria had previously realized.

Johnson nodded and began directing her team with hand signals and brief verbal instructions. They moved with coordinated precision, forming a loose perimeter around the largest concentration of birds while leaving escape routes that would funnel the chickens toward their transport carriers. "The trick is not to panic them more than they already are," Johnson explained to Maria as they watched the operation unfold. "Birds this size, they can hurt themselves pretty bad if they get too worked up. Broken wings, heart attacks from stress, that kind of thing. Plus, a scared rooster can do some real damage if he decides you're a threat to his flock."

The mention of aggressive roosters made Maria's pulse quicken again, and she found herself unconsciously stepping back from the nearest group of birds. The red rooster that Frank had identified as a troublemaker was living up to his reputation, puffing his feathers and making threatening gestures toward anyone who came too close to the hens he'd apparently claimed as his territory. His crow seemed louder than the others, more commanding, and Maria felt her newly developed phobia respond with a fresh wave of irrational terror that she struggled to suppress.

Officer Johnson noticed Maria's reaction and gave her a curious look. "You okay there? You look like someone just walked over your grave." The expression was one Maria's grandmother had used frequently, and hearing it now in this context made her think about inherited fears and unexplained anxieties. Was it possible that some people were simply predisposed to develop specific phobias, the way others inherited tendencies toward heart disease or diabetes? The thought was simultaneously comforting and disturbing—comforting because it suggested her condition might have a biological explanation rather than representing some fundamental failure of character, but disturbing because it implied the problem might be permanent rather than something she could simply overcome through willpower and professional training.

"Just not used to dealing with livestock," Maria said, which was true enough even if it didn't fully explain the severity of her reaction. "Most of my calls involve human suspects who at least theoretically respond to verbal commands and legal authority. These birds seem to have their own agenda." She attempted a laugh, but it came out sounding forced and hollow even to her own ears. Johnson's expression suggested she wasn't entirely buying the casual explanation, but she was professional enough not to press the issue while they were still managing an active incident.

The Animal Control team had succeeded in corralling about half of the escaped chickens, working with a combination of patience and strategic positioning that reminded Maria of certain types of police operations. The birds were loaded into transport carriers that would take them to a temporary holding facility while the insurance companies and legal departments sorted out liability issues. Frank Kowalski stood near his damaged truck, filling out paperwork and shaking his head periodically as he calculated the financial impact of the morning's disaster.

"Twenty-seven years," he repeated to anyone within earshot, as if the length of his employment record should have provided some protection against mechanical failures and escaped poultry. "Never had nothing like this happen before. That latch should've held. Gonna have to have a serious conversation with the maintenance department when I get back to the depot." His voice carried the resignation of a working man who understood that accidents happened regardless of experience or good intentions, but who still felt personally responsible for the chaos that had resulted from circumstances largely beyond his control.

Maria found herself oddly comforted by Frank's steady stream of commentary, partly because it gave her something to focus on other than the remaining birds, but also because his matter-of-fact acceptance of the situation helped normalize what she was experiencing. Accidents happened, even to people with decades of experience. Systems failed despite careful maintenance and proper procedures. Sometimes the world simply refused to cooperate with human plans and expectations, and the best anyone could do was adapt to changing circumstances and try to minimize the damage.

The philosophical implications of that realization struck her as potentially relevant to her own situation. Perhaps her sudden development of what appeared to be an intense phobia of roosters was simply another example of life's unpredictability, no different in principle from Frank's mechanical failure or the dozens of other random events that had shaped her police career. The thought didn't make her physical symptoms any less distressing, but it provided a framework for understanding her condition that didn't require self-blame or professional shame.

One of the Animal Control officers, a young man who looked barely old enough to have graduated from high school, was having trouble with a particularly stubborn group of hens that had taken refuge in the narrow space between two parked cars. His repeated attempts to guide them toward the transport carriers were being frustrated by their apparent determination to remain in what they perceived as a safe hiding spot. Johnson called out suggestions and encouragement, but the birds seemed to have developed their own strategy for dealing with the situation that didn't align with official capture protocols.

"Sometimes they just decide they like where they are," Johnson explained to Maria as they watched the young officer's increasingly creative attempts to dislodge the hiding birds. "Can't really blame them, when you think about it. From their perspective, they were minding their own business in a nice secure truck, and suddenly their whole world got turned upside down. Now they're in a strange place with unfamiliar sounds and smells, and everyone wants them to go somewhere else they've never seen before. Makes perfect sense they'd want to stay put once they found a spot that felt safe."

The parallel to Maria's own psychological state was so obvious that she wondered if Johnson was deliberately drawing the comparison or simply making casual conversation about animal behavior. Either way, the observation resonated with something deep in Maria's consciousness, a recognition that her sudden fear of roosters might represent her mind's attempt to create safety and predictability in a world that had somehow become more threatening than she'd previously realized. The idea that fear could be a rational response to perceived danger, even when that perception wasn't entirely accurate, suggested that her condition might be treatable rather than representing some fundamental character flaw.

**Chapter 2**

The rest of Maria's shift passed without incident, but she found herself hyperaware of every sound that might remotely resemble a rooster's crow. Car horns seemed more piercing than usual, the screech of bus brakes made her flinch, and even the laughter of children playing in a schoolyard caused her to turn her head anxiously, searching for the source of what her nervous system interpreted as potential threats. By the time she returned to the precinct at the end of her tour, she felt mentally and physically exhausted in a way that had nothing to do with the actual demands of police work and everything to do with maintaining constant vigilance against an enemy that existed primarily in her own mind.

Ray Kowalski was waiting for her in the parking lot, leaning against his personal vehicle with the patient air of someone who had been there for a while. His presence wasn't entirely surprising—they often coordinated their schedules to grab dinner or drinks after particularly difficult shifts—but something in his expression suggested this wasn't a casual social invitation. He'd worked with enough cops over the years to recognize the signs of someone struggling with job-related stress, and Maria's recent behavior had triggered his professional concern as well as his personal friendship. The fact that she'd been partnered with him for eight years without ever showing signs of psychological distress only made her current condition more alarming from his perspective.

"We need to talk," he said without preamble, falling into step beside her as she walked toward her own car. "And before you tell me everything's fine, I already heard about the chicken truck incident this morning. Johnson from Animal Control called the precinct to ask if you were feeling okay, said you looked like you were about to pass out in the middle of Penn Avenue." His voice carried the gentle but firm tone he typically used when dealing with victims who were reluctant to discuss traumatic experiences, a technique he'd developed over two decades of police work and refined through countless interactions with people who preferred to minimize their own suffering rather than admit they needed help.

Maria's first instinct was to deflect with humor or redirect the conversation toward Ray's concerns, but the events of the past few days had left her feeling too drained for elaborate deceptions. She unlocked her car and sat in the driver's seat with the door open, staring at the steering wheel while she tried to formulate an explanation that wouldn't sound completely insane to her pragmatic partner. The problem was that she didn't really understand what was happening to herself, which made it difficult to provide reassuring explanations to anyone else. How could she tell Ray that she'd developed an irrational terror of barnyard birds without sounding like she was having some kind of mental breakdown?

"I think I might be developing a phobia," she said finally, the words feeling strange and unfamiliar in her mouth. "I know how that sounds, especially coming from someone who's been doing this job as long as I have, but something's changed in the last few days. Ever since that cockfighting bust, I can't seem to handle being around roosters without having what feels like a panic attack." The admission felt both liberating and terrifying, acknowledging the reality of her condition while simultaneously making it more concrete and therefore more threatening to her sense of professional identity.

Ray's expression shifted from concern to something that might have been relief, as if her willingness to discuss the problem represented progress toward solving it. He'd seen too many cops try to handle psychological difficulties on their own, usually with results that damaged both their personal lives and their professional effectiveness. The fact that Maria was recognizing and naming her condition suggested she retained enough self-awareness to potentially address it before it became career-threatening. "Phobias are treatable," he said, settling into a comfortable position against her car where they could talk privately without attracting attention from other officers. "My cousin developed one after a car accident, couldn't drive over bridges for almost two years. Went to a therapist who specialized in that kind of thing, and now she's fine. Takes time and work, but it's not permanent unless you ignore it."

The comparison to post-accident trauma was both encouraging and troubling for Maria, encouraging because it suggested her condition had precedent and established treatment protocols, but troubling because it implied some kind of psychological injury that she couldn't identify or remember experiencing. The cockfighting bust had been unpleasant but not particularly traumatic by police standards, certainly nothing compared to some of the violent crime scenes she'd processed over the years. What made that particular incident different enough to trigger such a dramatic psychological response? Was it possible that cumulative stress from decades of police work had finally reached some kind of tipping point, with roosters serving as an arbitrary focal point for anxieties that actually had much deeper roots?

"The thing is, I can't figure out what caused it," Maria said, voicing her confusion about the timing and specificity of her symptoms. "I've dealt with plenty of situations that were more objectively stressful than a bunch of guys betting on chicken fights. Remember that domestic violence call last month where the suspect had a shotgun and three hostages? Or the gang shooting in East Liberty where we had to secure a scene with four bodies while the neighbors were throwing bottles at us?
